event.vectors 0.1.3.1

    • Event Space and Graph Reduction

    Event Space and Graph Reduction

    Event-Space-and-Graph-Reduction.Rmd
    library(event.vectors)

    Event Space

    Given event space \(\mathbb{E}\) with \(k\) independent event groupings: \[ \mathbb{E}:=\hat{e}_1 + \hat{e}_2+ \hat{e}_3 + \cdots + \hat{e}_k \] and corresponding heterogeneous data tables (\(\mathbb{D} :=D_1,D_2,D_3,\cdots,D_k\)) each having a “join-key” (\(J\), a column or column tuple shared across \(\mathbb{D}\)), an event vector (\(\overrightarrow{V_q}\)) is formed having values indicating the existence or absence of selection over \(D_k\) predicated on \(q\) unique values \(\forall J\):

    \[ \overrightarrow{V_q}:= \exists \sigma_{j_q \in J}(D_k) \Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_1 + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_2 + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_3 + \cdots + \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_{q}\hat{e}_k \\ q :=\text{ the q}^{th}\text{ distinct value in }J\enspace \forall \mathbb{D} \\ \sigma_{j_q \in J}(D_k) \equiv \dot{D_{qk}}:=\text{ predicated selection operation in a relational algebra context} \]

    From each \(\overrightarrow{V_q}\), \(q\) subsets over \(\mathbb{D}\) are derived as \(\Gamma_q:=D_{k_q}|\overrightarrow{V_q}\ne\emptyset\). The number of records (\(n\)) resulting from selection across the data sets can be represented as an array of row vectors:

    \[ \Gamma_q\longrightarrow \text{Distinct row counts over}\dot{D_{k_q}}\Rightarrow\begin{array} ((n_{11}&n_{12}&n_{13}&\cdots&n_{1k})\\ (n_{21}&n_{22}&n_{23}&\cdots&n_{2k})\\ (n_{31}&n_{32}&n_{33}&\cdots&n_{3k})\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ (n_{q1}&n_{q2}&n_{q3}&\cdots&n_{qk}) \end{array} \]

    Graph Reduction

    Next, considering a fully-connected graph having \(\beta\) nodes and number of edges given as follows: \[ \begin{align} K\rightarrow f(\beta) := {\beta\choose2} \equiv \frac{\beta(\beta-1)}{2} \end{align} \] and taking into account that event.vectors creates separate graphs for each \(q\), the number of edges per fully-connected graph \(G_q\) is given as follows:

    \[ \beta_q := \sum_{i=1}^q\Gamma_i \Rightarrow (\beta_1,\beta_2,\beta_3,\cdots,\beta_q)\\ K_q \rightarrow f(\beta_q) := {\beta_q\choose2} \] , which is also the number of comparisons to be carried out computationally.

    \(K_q\) can be reduced by projecting a set of logically-reduced predicates (as mentioned earlier) to interim results before creating each of the \(q\) graphs:

    \[ P_m:m\text{ predicates}\Rightarrow \begin{pmatrix}0\\1\end{pmatrix}_m\\ \dot\beta_q:=\forall i \in q\rightarrow\Gamma_i*\Pi (P_m|\dot D_{k_i})\\ 0 \le \dot\beta_q\le\beta_q \] This can quickly result in not only edge reduction but graph elimination for each \(q\) (\(\Gamma_q\) can easily become sparse). Trial and error may needed to fine-tune how graphs are generated as well as improve execution performance which is why the graph.control argument is provided for event.vectors::make.evs_universe() to allow for operating on graphs after the fact.
